item.title: C++ Notes: Literals [Part-1]
item.content:encoded:
C++ Series

  • C++ Notes: Literals [Part-1]

    literals


I had a long dream of learning C++ properly, and due the lockdown during Covid19 pandemic I finally had the chance to review my learnings and fix what I knew wrong. I will be writing notes on C++ to make my learnings persistent. They won't be in depth as other articles of C++ experts. I didn't get any chance to work anywhere as a C++ developer, there might be silly or grave mistakes here and there. For the time being, I will ignore those and just move along to maintain my flow.

References

Most of the codes are inpired from the book The C++ Standard Library by Rainer Grimm and C++ Reference. I really like his teaching and coding style. He published multiple outstanding C++ books.

Let's begin, shall we?

Literals

Definition of Literals

Literals are explicit values in the program.


Value of literal is fixed, it can also be referred as constants. Literal can be value of basic types such as int, bool etc.

Built in C++ literals are shown below.

main.cpp
1#include <iostream>
2
3int main(){
4  // Unsigned integer
5  int unsigned_int = u'U';
6  // Hexadecimal
7  int hex = 0x2b;
8  // Raw string
9  std::string raw = R"(Raw String)";
10  std::cout << unsigned_int << ", " << hex << ", " << raw << std::endl;
11}

Output

185, 42, Raw String
  • Literals are not restricted to values, even lambda function can be a function literal
1lambda function[](std::string text) { return text.length(); }

Raw string literals

Anything between the delimiters of raw string becomes a part of the string.

1#include <iostream>
2
3const char* string1 = R"foo(
4  Hello
5  World
6  )foo";
7
8int main (){
9  std::cout << string1 << std::endl;
10}

Output

1Hello
2  World

Built in literals

Let's see a self explanatory example.

1#include <iostream>
2// We need to include chrono to work
3#include <chrono>
4
5// We are going to use c++ standard library's chrono literals
6using namespace std::chrono_literals;
7
8int main(){
9  // Let's declare 1 hour by using h literal
10  std::chrono::hours one_hour = 1h;
11  // Let's convert one hour to seconds
12  auto time_in_seconds = std::chrono::duration_cast<std::chrono::seconds>(one_hour);
13  std::cout << time_in_seconds.count() << std::endl;
14}

Output


13600

User defined literals


There are six major categories of literals in C++.

  1. integer
  2. chracter
  3. floating-point
  4. string
  5. boolean
  6. pointer
User defined literal operator signatures

1ReturnType operator "" _a(unsigned long long int);   // Literal operator for user-defined INTEGRAL literal
2ReturnType operator "" _b(long double);              // Literal operator for user-defined FLOATING literal
3ReturnType operator "" _c(char);                     // Literal operator for user-defined CHARACTER literal
4ReturnType operator "" _d(wchar_t);                  // Literal operator for user-defined CHARACTER literal
5ReturnType operator "" _e(char16_t);                 // Literal operator for user-defined CHARACTER literal
6ReturnType operator "" _f(char32_t);                 // Literal operator for user-defined CHARACTER literal
7ReturnType operator "" _g(const char*, size_t);      // Literal operator for user-defined STRING literal
8ReturnType operator "" _h(const wchar_t*, size_t);   // Literal operator for user-defined STRING literal
9ReturnType operator "" _i(const char16_t*, size_t);  // Literal operator for user-defined STRING literal
10ReturnType operator "" _g(const char32_t*, size_t);  // Literal operator for user-defined STRING literal
11ReturnType operator "" _r(const char*);              // Raw literal operator
12template<char...> ReturnType operator "" _t();       // Literal operator template

Cooked vs Raw literals

A user-defined literal that accepts as input whatever type the compiler assigned to the literal value is unofficially known as cooked literal.

Operator defined by the user which accepts the literal as sequence of char values, then it's up to the user how to interpret the literal is called raw literal.

Let's take a look at an example.

1#include <iostream>
2#include <string>
3
4double operator"" _km(const char *km){
5  std::cout << "Raw _km" << std::endl;
6  // Converting const char* to double, requires <string>
7  return std::stod(km);
8}
9
10// Based on the signature above
11double operator"" _m(unsigned long long meter){
12  std::cout << "Cooked _m" << std::endl;
13  return double(meter);
14}
15
16int main(){
17  auto distance_km = 100.5_km;
18  std::cout << distance_km << std::endl;
19  std::cout << "Type: " << typeid(distance_km).name() << std::endl;
20
21  std::cout << std::endl;
22
23  auto distance_m = 100_m;
24  std::cout << distance_m << std::endl;
25  std::cout << "Type: " << typeid(distance_m).name() << std::endl;
26}

Output


1Raw _km
2100.5
3Type: d
4
5Cooked _m
6100
7Type: d

If we implement both cooked and raw both forms the compiler will use the cooked form since it has higher priority.


1#include <iostream>
2#include <string>
3
4using namespace std;
5
6double operator"" _km(const char* km){
7    std::cout << "Raw _km" << std::endl;
8    return std::stod(km);
9}
10
11long double operator"" _km(long double km){
12    std::cout << "Cooked _km" << std::endl;
13    return km;
14}
15
16int main()
17{
18    auto distance_km = 100.0_km;
19    std::cout << distance_km << std::endl;
20}

Output


1Cooked _km
2100

Usecase

Always save distance as meter.

1#include <iostream>
2#include <ostream>
3
4namespace MeterDistance {
5 class Distance {
6 public:
7    Distance (double i) : meter(i) {}
8
9     friend std::ostream& operator << (std::ostream& out, const Distance &a){
10         out << a.meter << " m";
11         return out;
12     }
13
14 private:
15     double meter;
16 };
17
18 namespace Unit {
19 Distance operator ""_km(long double d){
20     return Distance(d * 1000);
21 }
22 }
23}
24
25using MeterDistance::Distance;
26using namespace MeterDistance::Unit;
27
28int main()
29{
30    Distance d(1.0_km);
31    std::cout << d << std::endl;
32}

Output


11000 m

In the next episode we will take a look at enumerators and pointers.
